dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So what do you know about infinity?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I think it means that it's really just something that's infinite, that never ends.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: That's a great way to think about it. Infinity is something that never ends, where finite, the opposite of infinity, refers to a process or a quantity that we could actually count all the way through, at least in theory if given enough time. So if you had to guess, how many Skittles are in this jar?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I would say about like 217.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: 217. And if we wanted to figure out the exact number, how would we find out? We could put them all out and divide them into pieces of five and then we could use that. Yeah, absolutely. In fact, I did that before you got here, and it's 649 Skittles. Here's a much harder question. How many pieces of glitter do you think are in that jar?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Maybe like 4,012.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: I'll admit. I have absolutely no idea. Do you think it's a finite number or an infinite number?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Finite because I can see them all in here.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, you can see them all. And in fact, if we were really, really, really patient, we could do the same thing as with the Skittles. But here's another question. You said that there's a finite amount of glitter in that jar, and I agree. So how many jars would we need to hold an infinite amount of glitter?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: An infinite amount of jars.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Very good. Why do you say that?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Because if there's unlimited pieces of glitter, we need unlimited pieces of jar.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So let's try and imagine infinitely many jars. Would they fit in this room?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, absolutely not. Because this room holds only a finite amount of space. And in fact, infinitely many jars would not even fit in something called the observable universe, which is the portion of the universe that astronomers can see. Really how does that make you feel?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: That makes me feel like my brain is exploding.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, that makes me feel like my brain is exploding.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Can infinity ever get bigger?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: That's a wonderful question, a very rich question. What do you think?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I think maybe because you said it was unlimited.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: You have very good intuition. So there are ways that mathematicians can build infinite collections of things. And if you repeat those processes, it's in fact possible to build even bigger and bigger sizes of infinity. So what have you learned today about infinity?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I've learned that even if it's unlimited, there are many different ways of making infinity and you can never actually see it all.
